thread.title: Hashtag calls for Star Wars boycott
thread.title_full: Hashtag calls for Star Wars boycott

title: Hashtag calls for Star Wars boycott
text:
Hashtag calls for Star Wars boycott Twitter user says film 'promotes white genocide' Published 7:51 AM CDT Oct 20, 2015 Photos 
Disney/LucasFilm 
A Twitter hashtag that began appearing Sunday evening calls for a boycott to the new Star Wars movie. 
The latest trailer for "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" debuted on ESPN during this week's Monday night football game, perhaps the most anticipated halftime outside of a Super Bowl. 
The trailer introduces us once again to Daisy Ridley's Rey and John Boy... 
"Star Wars" fans overwhelmed online ticket sellers Monday as the new "Force Awakens" trailer gave them their best look yet at Han Solo, Princess Leia, and new characters like Daisy Ridley's Rey. 
The tickets were initially expected to go one sale after... 'Star Wars: The Force Awakens' trailer premiering on... 
Disney will use one of its powerful sports franchises on Monday to promote one of its most lucrative movie brands: Star Wars. 
The trailer for "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" will make its debut during halftime of ESPN's Monday Night Football game betwe... 
Some of those using the hashtag are claiming "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" is "promoting white genocide," as tweeted by an account called End Cultural Marxism. 
The film is presumed to contain a lead stormtrooper role played by black actor John Boyega. 
Another account, called Critical Spooking, tweeted the hashtag and said the new film is "nothing more than a social justice propaganda piece that alienates it's (sic) core audience of young white males." 
According to the Hollywood Reporter, mentioned that past installments in the Star Wars franchise have included leads played by actors of color, including the fact that James Earl Jones voiced iconic villain Darth Vader throughout the original trilogy. 
The final trailer for the highly anticipated film aired Monday evening during halftime of Monday Night Football to much fanfare.
